_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Henkel Corporation Elgin Facility, uses toluene 2,4-diisocyanate (TDS) and toluene diisocyanate (TDI) which are considered hazardous by the EPA.  The same properties that make TDS and TDI valuable as reactants at our facility also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions when handling TDS and TDI to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our coworkers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle TDS and TDI combined with (1) safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, (2) the safe handling procedures that we use, and (3) the training of our personnel.



The primary purpose of the Elgin facility is to produce polyurethane coatings and adhesives, which are shipped to a contracted warehouse prior to sale or directly to customers to be used in a variety of applications ranging from composite construction materials to food and medical instrument packaging.  TDS and TDI are two of the reactants used in the manufacture of these products.  TDS and TDI is received by tank truck and stored in an indoor storage tanks that are contained to prevent the loss of any material outside of the building should a massive failure occur.  The TDS and TDI are pumped to vessels within the same building, where they are mixed with other reactants, solvents and additives to form the finished coating or adhesive. The final product is then pumped into drums or pails for shipment to our customers. 



Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, management personnel and contractors.  TDS and TDI are the only substance handled at this facility that are regulated by EPA's risk management program (RMP) rule.  



The Elgin facility has Spill Prevention Contingency plans.  These plans emphasize engineering controls where practical and detai

l procedures to follow should a release occur as well as training requirements for those employees involved. 



There have been no accidental releases of TDS or TDI at the Elgin facility in the past five years.



Our emergency response program is based upon the requirements in OSHA's Hazardous Waste and Emergency Operations (HAZWOPER) regulation (29 CFR 1910.120).  The site is also covered under the OSHA PSM program requirements. The Elgin Facility's emergency response plan calls for notification of the local fire department and any potential neighbors.
